What are the symptoms of altitude sickne.generation: Altitude sickness, also known as acute mountain sickness (AMS), occurs when the body cannot adjust to the lower oxygen levels at higher elevations. The most common symptom is headache, but others may include nausea, vomiting, dizziness and fatigue. Some people also experience shortness of breath. Symptoms tend to improve within 24 hours as the body adjusts to the change in elevation. If symptoms persist or worsen, individuals should descend to a lower altitude.

How can you prevent altitude sickness?.generation: Preventing altitude sickness begins with being prepared. It is important to drink plenty of fluids, eat light meals, avoid alcohol, and rest at high elevations before traveling to higher altitudes. If you start experiencing symptoms of altitude sickness, try to descend to lower altitudes, and seek medical attention immediately if your symptoms become worse.

How is altitude sickness treated?.generation: Altitude sickness, or acute mountain sickness, is usually treated with rest, oxygen, acetazolamide, or a combination of all of these. Acetazolamide is a drug that helps speed up the rate at which your body gets used to high altitudes. It is often prescribed when traveling to higher elevations, although it should not be taken without medical advice. Rest, oxygen and acetazolamide are also used to treat altitude sickness.

What causes altitude sickness?.generation: Altitude sickness, also known as acute mountain sickness, occurs when the body cannot adjust to lower amounts of oxygen at high altitudes. As altitude increases, the air pressure decreases, and less oxygen is available in each breath. When people reach a certain elevation, their bodies produce substances to help with this decrease in oxygen levels. If a person ascends too rapidly, his or her body may not have time to adjust to the change in oxygen levels, and altitude sickness can result.

Can altitude sickness become severe or l.generation: Yes. In rare cases, altitude sickness can progress to a serious or life-threatening condition. This is known as high-altitude pulmonary edema (HAPE) or high-altitude cerebral edema (HACE), both of which can occur at elevations greater than 2,500 meters above sea level. HACE can occur within 48 hours of arriving at a high altitude and is marked by confusion and delirium. It is more likely to occur in those with chronic lung disease and/or heart problems. HAPE occurs when fluid collects in the lungs and can cause respiratory distress and shortness of breath. HAPE occurs within 24 to 36 hours of arrival at a high altitude.

How quickly can symptoms of altitude sic.generation: The symptoms of altitude sickness can appear anywhere from 24 hours to 2 days after ascending to high altitudes. Symptoms of altitude sickness include headache, dizziness, fatigue, nausea and vomiting, difficulty sleeping, loss of appetite, shortness of breath, and swollen hands and feet. These symptoms can vary in intensity, and some people may only experience mild symptoms while others may develop more severe symptoms. If you develop any of these symptoms, you should descend to lower altitudes as soon as possible.

What is Alopecia areata?.generation: Alopecia areata is an autoimmune condition that causes hair loss on the head, face and other parts of the body. Although alopecia areata can affect anyone at any age, it most commonly occurs in children, teens and young adults. It is estimated that between 0.1 percent and 0.2 percent of the U.S. population suffers from this condition. The good news is that the vast majority of people with this condition will experience hair regrowth within a year.

What are the common symptoms of Alopecia.generation: The common symptom of Alopecia areata is sudden hair loss in patches. In many cases, hair grows back within six months. But sometimes, it doesn't, and the hair may never grow back. Other symptoms include burning or tingling sensations in the scalp, as well as a rash. If a person experiences these symptoms, it is important to see a dermatologist, as the doctor can determine what the best course of treatment is.

How is Alopecia areata diagnosed?.generation: Alopecia areata is diagnosed by a medical professional using a visual examination. The hair loss will be visible and the diagnosis will be obvious. Sometimes, a biopsy of the bald patch will be necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

What are the different treatment options.generation: Alopecia areata is an autoimmune disorder that causes patchy hair loss. While there is no known cure, there are several treatment options available. One option is steroid cream. Another is immunosuppressants. These are medications that work by suppressing the body’s immune system. Finally, biologic therapy is an option. Which groups of people are most at risk.generation: Anyone can develop alopecia areata, but certain factors put people at a higher risk than others. What are the symptoms of chronic kidney.generation: Chronic kidney disease is a progressive loss of kidney function that is not reversible. It occurs slowly over time, so individuals may not experience any symptoms for years. As the kidneys continue to lose function, they are no longer able to filter waste products from the blood, causing waste products to build up in the bloodstream. These waste products can affect many organs in the body and may result in swollen feet or ankles, fatigue, nausea, loss of appetite, and confusion.

How is chronic kidney disease diagnosed?.generation: Diagnosis of chronic kidney disease begins with a simple blood test that checks for the presence of creatinine, which is a waste product filtered out by the kidneys. In addition, a blood test to check for glomerular filtration rate (GFR) can be used to assess kidney function. Other tests may include a urinalysis, imaging tests such as ultrasounds or X-rays, and a kidney biopsy.

What treatments are available for chroni.generation: Chronic kidney disease is usually treated by slowing its progression. There are many medications and treatments available for chronic kidney disease that help control symptoms, slow down the progression of the disease, and even reverse some of the damage caused by kidney disease. These include blood pressure medications, medications to decrease swelling, medications to lower phosphorous levels, vitamin D supplements, medications to improve red blood cell production, and dialysis. In advanced cases, a person may need a kidney transplant.

What can cause chronic kidney disease?.generation: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) occurs when a person's kidneys lose the ability to filter waste products from the blood. CKD can be caused by many things, including high blood pressure, diabetes, obesity, smoking and heredity. Other factors that increase the risk of developing CKD include age, gender and race. African Americans are more likely than white people to develop CKD. Hispanic Americans are more likely to have CKD than non-Hispanic whites. Men are more likely to have CKD than women. People with diabetes are more likely to have CKD than those without diabetes.

What are the stages of chronic kidney di.generation: There are five stages of chronic kidney disease. Stage 1 means that you have normal kidney function. In stage 2, your glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is between 90 and 89 mL/min/1.73m2. Stage 3 is classified as mild chronic kidney disease, as your GFR is between 60 and 59 mL/min/1.73m2. In stage 4, your GFR is between 30 and 59 mL/min/1.73m2 and your kidneys are no longer working properly. Stage 5 is classified as severe chronic kidney disease, as your GFR is less than 30 mL/min/1.73m2.

How can the progression of chronic kidne.generation: Chronic kidney disease is progressive, meaning it gets worse over time. There are many things that people can do to help slow its progression. These include maintaining a healthy weight, getting enough sleep, eating a healthy diet, getting regular exercise, managing your blood pressure, and monitoring your blood sugar level. It's also important to follow the advice of your doctor regarding lifestyle changes and medications.

How is Pellagra treated?.generation: The primary treatment for pellagra is to increase vitamin B3 (niacin) intake. Which vitamin deficiency leads to Pellag.generation: Niacin deficiency, also known as Pellagra, is a condition that results from a lack of niacin, also called vitamin B3. What are varicose veins?.generation: Varicose veins are enlarged and dilated blood vessels near the surface of the skin. What are the symptoms of varicose veins?.generation: Varicose veins are enlarged and dilated blood vessels that are usually blue, purple or dark reddish-brown in color. What treatment options are available for.generation: Treatment for varicose veins depends on the severity of the problem. This procedure involves cutting out and tying off the vein so that it cannot return blood to the heart.

What are the risk factors for developing.generation: Varicose veins occur when the valves inside the veins no longer work properly. How can one prevent varicose veins?.generation: Varicose veins can be prevented with lifestyle changes that promote circulation in the legs. What are the symptoms of dysentery?.generation: Dysentery is defined as an acute intestinal inflammation accompanied by bloody or mucoid stool. What are the typical symptoms of dementi.generation: The symptoms of dementia will vary depending on the underlying cause. What are the most common treatments for.generation: Dementia is a general term used to describe the decline in cognitive function that occurs in many diseases. How does dementia affect daily life?.generation: Dementia is a chronic disease that affects the way a person thinks, acts and feels. What are some known risk factors for dem.generation: Some risk factors for dementia include advancing age, family history of dementia, head injury, Down syndrome, and vascular conditions. What are some strategies for managing th.generation: Although dementia is a chronic condition, there are steps that individuals and their families can take to help manage the symptoms. How does cellulitis spread within the bo.generation: Cellulitis spreads by entering the body through breaks in the skin, such as cuts or scrapes.
